On Mon, 11 Oct 2004 19:36:33 -0400, Joseph Reisinger
<joeraii@...> wrote:
> Not only that, in a larger sense, different phenotypic modules exhibit
> different mutation rates based on their connectivity. For example, take
> some regulatory pathway 'A' that is very short but highly conserved
> across several different modules. A mutation on 'A' will then affect
> all of those modules. Whereas a mutation in as less-conserved process,
> say 'B,' would have a smaller phenotypic effect.
> 
> Thus not only the mechanism of crossover and DNA transcription, but
> also development itself affects what we think of as phenotypic
> mutation.
> 
> -- Joe

Um. So perhaps mutation rate could be applied at a level below the
whole individual but above each weight? Perhaps each node might have a
characteristic that controls the mutation rate of its connections -
perhaps just the in- or out-bound ones, to avoid resolving the
different levels at each end.

That way we might see the development of more volatile sections, where
the search space is being traversed more aggressively.

Or not. Although I find the idea attractive to a degree, I think this
may be a technique that might be more beneficial to, say, SANE, where
the node is the individual.

Mike
